title: As of 28 December 2017, how many cholera deaths will the Humanitarian Data Exchange record in Yemen?
preds: seems like they are not going to update
2226 cholera deaths according to WHO as of 17 Dec. Latest HDX number is from 26 Nov: 2219.
"On 30 September 2017, the World Health Organization reported 771,945 cases of cholera with 2,132 death cases." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Yemen_cholera_outbreak
According to Guardian and WHO a million cases expected by the end of the year. With death rate 1/40 - 1/400

Cholora is caused by poor sanitation of ignorant people living in primitive conditions. There might be chaos caused by terrorists in Yemen, but that doesn't make the people of yemen become stupid enough to drink water contaminated with their own feces.
If they update, I think it it's possible there could be more than 2300 but not much time remains for an update.

ICRC estimates 1,000,000 total cases to date. Reports 8 consecutive weeks of declining cases. 2,226 deaths since April and the WHO reports 1 death last week.  -- This  cholera epidemic is remeniscent of the Ebola outbreak in Africa, in that the prevention is similar, and once the population understands  the habits required to avoid contamination, the cases fall dramatically.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-42440805

New WHO data!  http://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/yemen/Yemen_Cholera_Response_-_Weekly_Epidemiological_Bulletin_-_W50_2017_Dec_11-Dec_17.pdf?ua=1 They skipped week 49, and only published this week (week 50). 7 further deaths (total 2226) in last 2 weeks, and - as mentioned in the report - only a single death in this last week.   So ... Strong evidence that the epidemic is over, and strong suggestion that WHO (and thus HDX) are highly unlikely to be regularly updating from this point forward.

We're 81 potential deaths away from 2300; the last 81 deaths began to occur in early October, so the death rate per time would need to nearly double between the last measurement and the end of the year. Blockade was late November; unclear if its effects are in in the most recently published (late November) data. Even if they aren't (& indeed possibly there were no such effects), doubling the rate would be a substantial increase. So I remain skewed toward the 2,300 bucket. I still think it's possible the number jumps significantly enough to pass 2300 in December, but I think more than 2500 is remote.

Now 3 weeks since the last WHO "weekly" update, and 38 days since the last "daily" update. I would have said "game over", but I note that two days ago, HDX (finally) updated using the last WHO "weekly update".   So on one hand, it means that although HDX has not given up the ghost, it is unlikely that HDX will be getting too many more updates before 28 December.  Even if there are more than 2300 deaths at that date, HDX may not capture that fact. On the other hand, the decreased frequency of WHO reporting suggests that the number of deaths has indeed continued to decline.  (Alternatively: civil breakdown means inability to report.)  Even if reporting was happening on a daily basis, it is now likely that the reporting would show much fewer than 2300 deaths. In either case, "Less than 2300" is the uber-strong favourite outcome here.

HDX not updating.
WHO's weekly epidemiological bulletins can be found here:
http://www.emro.who.int/yem/yemeninfocus/situation-reports.html Most recent is a few weeks old, however. WHO numbers:
26 Nov: 2219
19 Nov: 2211
5 Nov: 2192
29 Oct: 2185 35 per month at that rate. HDX may fail to update. Number probably won't pass 2300 before end of year anyway. There may be reporting problems, but there are only 2 weeks left to remedy them.
Silence from the WHO for 2wk now.
Switching totally to under 2,300 because tracking seems to have stopped.

Not only no daily update on the WHO website since the 8 November, but also the last "weekly update" was released 8.5 days ago. INCREASE probability per week that HDX will "give up" (due to lack of WHO daily data): 0.25 -> 0.40
(In other words, 89.5% likely that HDX will stop updating some time before 28 December.) Forecast number of deaths by the end of the year:  2250 (based on the WHO data as of 26 November).

2196. Not updated since 8 November.  WHO is reporting 2219 deaths as of 26 Nov. (Thanks @Ken_Barns.)
http://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/yemen/Yemen_Cholera_Response_-_Weekly_Epidemiological_Bulletin_-_W47_2017_28Nov_20-Nov_2629.pdf?ua=1 That would mean 35 cholera deaths reported in November.
52 in October.
94 in September. It looks like cholera is in decline, but we're pretty close to 2300. Not sure how the blockade is affecting reporting. If it's suppressing the numbers, they could jump suddenly when more information is available.

Heading lower because no one has bothered to publish updated numbers in weeks and that suggests either that the problem is getting less severe or monitoring isn't working. Either way I don't expect to see a big jump in case numbers.

New WHO publication for the week 20-26 November here ... http://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/yemen/Yemen_Cholera_Response_-_Weekly_Epidemiological_Bulletin_-_W47_2017_28Nov_20-Nov_2629.pdf?ua=1 HDX indicates that they are using the WHO's _daily_ updates, but the WHO have not published daily updates since 8 Nov.  The WHO are still publishing weekly epidemiology updates.  However, in the last few days, they have removed the links to the daily updates from their page at http://www.emro.who.int/yem/yemeninfocus/situation-reports.html
This suggests to me that they are no longer planning to provide daily updates. UPDATE number of days remaining.
INCREASE probability per week that HDX will "give up" (because the WHO stops daily updates): 0.10 -> 0.25
DECREASE expected number of deaths per day if _no_ further outbreak: 1.3 -> 1.0

Asjusting up as the Arab Press says the unspoken outloud - “The front lines have barely moved in months. The Houthis show no sign of giving up. More airstrikes are not likely to bring a decision. So the Saudi strategy by default is to rely on famine and disease to wear down the Yemeni people. All sides in this war are guilty of perpetuating a catastrophe, but the blockade and airstrikes are the principal cause of the famine and cholera. The Saudi government and leadership should be held accountable for their actions. A strategy of starvation is unacceptable.” Read more: http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2017/11/lebanon-saudi-hariri-mohammed-bin-salman-iran.html#ixzz4zpNkqaDp

Absence of evidence (recent updates tabulating death from cholera) is not evidence of absence of cholera deaths; on the other hand, if the WHO never manages to update the data for whatever reason,* we'll just end up in the "Less than 2,300" bucket. *One source of potential distraction: maybe WHO should give Mugabe an award, or a high-level position, now that he has more time on his hands. (More gravely, WHO workers on the ground in Yemen are likely doing heroic work through a blockade and potential scrutiny of those with the power to impose it; guess we'll eventually see whether they're able to publish anything further.)

90 deaths in September
52 deaths in October
12 deaths in November, to date (11/8) Projecting an additional 50 days at the Oct./November rate equates to approx. 2271 deaths by 12/28 (75 deaths added to the current 2196). Expect this number is high due to the steady decline in monthly deaths.  The only governates with higher death counts in October over September were al Hudaydah (15 up from 14), Al Bayda (2 up from 1), and Lahj (1 up from 0).

Though the HDX site has not updated, the WHO has published data here: http://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/yemen/Yemen_Cholera_Response_-_Weekly_Epidemiological_Bulletin_-_W46_2017_Nov_13-Nov_19_2_3.pdf?ua=1 Compared to the latest HDX data, we are another 11 days down the track, and another 15 deaths.  To get into the next bracket (2300-2500), there will need to be another 89 deaths in 34 days ... and that is assuming that the HDX data is kept up to date. I finished the model.  Based on the following questions ...
a)  How likely are HDX to "give up" each week, and leave the data set incomplete?
b)  How likely is an outbreak each week?
c)  If an outbreak, what are the likely number of deaths each day?
d)  If no outbreak, what are the likely number of deaths each day?
e)  How much scatter can be expected around the figures in c) and d)?
d)  How much time remains? Most likely outcome is the status quo, leading to a gradual improvement, and deaths coming in under 2300 (47%).  Next most likely outcome is the HDX data collection becoming so sporadic that they fail to keep count, and their total gets "stuck" under 2300 regardless of what the actual death count is (39%).

Crunching the numbers.  Point Case Fatality Rate (as opposed to cumulative CFR) has been essentially bi-modal.  Before July, during the acceleration phase of the outbreak, the CFR was generally at or above 0.5% (1 in 200 cases died).  Since mid-August, the CFR has generally been at or below 0.05% (1 in 2000 cases die).  July and early August was a transition period between the two. So, given the 8 Nov data of 2196 deaths, it means that, in order to reach the 2300-2500 bracket, figures between 8 Nov and 28 Dec would need to demonstrate 2.1 deaths per day.  This would require either: DOUBLING the present number of cases per day, to 5000; or DOUBLING the present CFR to 0.08% (1 death in 1250 cases). Reaching the 2500-3000 bracket would require a return to the late-July peak transmission of cases (7000 cases per day) AND a more than doubling of the CFR. Reaching the 3000+ bracket becomes an exercise in improbability (essentially needing an entirely new outbreak). SO ... Present trends would indicate a forecast based on a bell-curve centred around 40 further deaths between 8 Nov and 28 Dec (or a total of around 2245). However, I see one of three possible outcomes here:
1.  Trends continue as above, with slight variations in rates of new cases, or in CFR.
2.  For whatever reason, HDX cannot or does not update their data all the way through until 28 December.
3.  Catastrophe, and a new cholera outbreak (though it is hard to imagine how things could be _worse_ in Yemen, without also removing the ability of HDX to report accurate data). Outcome 1:
Highly likely "Less than 2300", but small chance of "2300-2500". Outcome 2:
Almost certainty of "Less than 2300". Outcome 3:
Highly likely "2500-3000", roughly equal chances of "2300-2500" or "3000+". And of the 3 outcomes, I think Outcome 1 is by far the most likely. Provisional forecast above.  I'll fiddle with a probability/decision tree to give some more fine detail around the different outcomes later.

"[A] number of measures have been introduced recently by the coalition, effectively closing air, sea and land access to Yemen. I have told the [UN Security? which?] Council that unless those measures are lifted and five particular steps that I am going to run through are taken, there will be famine in Yemen...[:] the largest famine the world has seen for many decades, with millions of victims." http://ye.one.un.org/content/unct/yemen/en/home/news-centre/news/un-under-secretary-general-humanitarian-affairs-and-emergency-relief-coordinator-yemen-8november2017.html

Moving toward the lower bucket because I'm thinking the Saudi coalition may stop the WHO from issuing the reports that underlie this question (see links in the spreadsheet that determines the question) in which case the lowest bucket will win out. Interviewer: "Scott [Pelley], you've reported in many war zones. Usually humanitarian aid and reporters are able to get through. Is this unusual? Is this an extreme case?" Pelley: "It is an extreme case in my experience. I have never found a country so sealed off from the rest of the world as Yemen under the Saudi Coalition today. It's a very difficult place to get to and to have the Saudi blockade so secure over the entire country. It's very rare to have a situation in which you have this all-out war, millions of people facing famine, nearly a million people infected by cholera, and the world can't see it."
https://www.cbsnews.com/news/60-minutes-barred-from-yemen-still-got-the-footage/ The reporters failed to get into the country, and instead sent cameras into the country with humanitarian workers and asked those workers to take pictures. Here's an example: A starving child in Yemen who is 7 years old and weighs 11 pounds:
https://cbsnews2.cbsistatic.com/hub/i/r/2017/11/19/649c7ee4-5629-4b83-b8d2-f7726ce7442e/resize/770x/57f03bdac64d510d0b1d5ac7673f2917/ot-yemenb.jpg
Simple log-linear model, stochastic extrapolation of past 6 weeks trend of exponentially declining cases and CFR.
Children are most affected and have highest death rate.  there are 1 million cases expected and of these 600,000 will be children
Saudis don't want bad PR from this either and so will pressure news reports to lowball figures
Because the government will not permit to acknowledge the real data.
deaths seem to be tapering off, though extraneous factors complicating relief efforts need to be closely monitored.
Unrest complicating the ability of aid to reach areas where needed.
Based on other people's estimates and explanations here.
The rate of increase seems to have slowed in the last two months and I'm hopeful that by the end of the year deaths will only be a little over 2,300 at the current rate of growth.
With the UN pulling out, I worry data collection may be impeded.

The death rate has greatly declined, but the number of reported cases continues to climb. I should return to this question and do some actual math, but for now I'm going with my gut.  https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2017/oct/12/yemen-cholera-outbreak-worst-in-history-1-million-cases-by-end-of-year&ved=0ahUKEwi9lPTc1K7XAhUY32MKHVpQC4gQFggmMAA&usg=AOvVaw1rFz3d-A7ahpYdrzhFQ2jU http://public.tableau.com/views/001CholeraYemenTracker/CholeraYemenTracker?%3Aembed=y&%3AshowVizHome=no&%3Adisplay_count=y&%3Adisplay_static_image=y#!%2Fpublish-confirm
